instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00164A: What is 820-00164A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_LSOC_RST_L: What is SMC_LSOC_RST_L? SMC_LSOC_RST_L is a signal that comes out of the trackpad on Macbook Airs that can reset the SMC.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power button doesnt work
threads.message:
so I have this board, doesnt look liquid damaged, i press power button, the macbook will be shutdown, while at the same time, orange light go green light, which  I have read before, is <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> being dragged by <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is it ?
I have tried known good bottom case with new trackpad and keyboard flex but still the same, so I assume it will be logicboard problem
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is 3.4v, and drop when shorted, I have tried changing <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>
note : I have tried shorting power pads and power button from keyboard, still the same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power button doesnt work
threads.message: whole board looks pristine, just a bit of dust here and there, j4800 looks clean, is this smc problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power button doesnt work
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST_L</SIGNAL> level.
Try <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads (instead of power button), with trackpad flex disconnected; same issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power button doesnt work
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 380mv, the caps is not shorted
i have tried with <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16t pads with only board , but still the same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power button doesnt work
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 380mv"
That is the problem.
Everytime you pull down <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, you trigger SMC reset in fact.
If still low when remove <CAPACITOR>C4836</CAPACITOR>, then bad <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, TP flex/board, or J4800.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power button doesnt work
threads.message: I tried removing <CAPACITOR>C4836</CAPACITOR>, replacing <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, and removing the j4800 and tried smc on off, but smc <SIGNAL>RESET_L</SIGNAL> is still dragged down

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power button doesnt work
threads.message: Sorry, there's a bridge at my j4800, now its working, thanks a lot!
